items.title: Confusing error message when serializing set data type

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

items.body:
### What did you do?

In Python 3.8, I tried to serialize a Python dict whose value can be a set. `ujson` failed to `dumps()` it into a JSON string. It is expected. But the error message is quite confusing

```
Python 3.8.2 (default, Feb 26 2020, 02:56:10)
[GCC 7.4.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from ujson import dumps
>>> dumps(set())
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: �0d is not JSON serializable
``` 

### What did you expect to happen?

`ujson` should have better error message that helps debugging. Here is the error message in built-in `json` module

```
>>> from json import dumps
>>> dumps(set())
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/json/__init__.py", line 231, in dumps
    return _default_encoder.encode(obj)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/json/encoder.py", line 199, in encode
    chunks = self.iterencode(o, _one_shot=True)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/json/encoder.py", line 257, in iterencode
    return _iterencode(o, 0)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/json/encoder.py", line 179, in default
    raise TypeError(f'Object of type {o.__class__.__name__} '
TypeError: Object of type set is not JSON serializable
```

`json` module has much better error message

### What versions are you using?

* OS: Ubuntu 18.04
* Python: 3.8.2
* UltraJSON: 2.0.1

```python
from ujson import dumps
dumps(set())
```

items.title: ujson v2.x leaks memory
items.body:
### What did you do?

Serialize documents with `ujson`

### What did you expect to happen?

Memory consumption not to grow. With `ujson` v.1.35 the memory consumption doesn't grow at all.

### What actually happened?

Memory consumption grows with `ujson` versions 2.x. When you run `test()` from the example below the python process memory consumption grows constantly. The memory is not freed after the function finishes.

### What versions are you using?

* OS: tested on both macos 10.15.3 and CentOS 7
* Python: 3.7.7
* UltraJSON: 1.35, 2.x

Please include **code** that reproduces the issue.

The [best reproductions](https://stackoverflow.com/help/minimal-reproducible-example) are [self-contained scripts](https://ericlippert.com/2014/03/05/how-to-debug-small-programs/) with minimal dependencies.

```python
import random
import string

import ujson


def random_string(n):
    return "".join(random.choices(string.ascii_uppercase + string.digits, k=n))


def random_dict(n_keys):
    return dict((random_string(5), random_string(20)) for _ in range(n_keys))


def gen_docs(n_docs):
    for _ in range(n_docs):
        yield random_dict(20)


def test(n_docs):
    for doc in gen_docs(n_docs):
        ujson.dumps(doc)
```

items.title: ujson throws type error for plist file on Ubuntu, but doesn't for same file on MacOS
items.body:
I've tested this with an empty plist file, with the following contents:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE plist PUBLIC "-//Apple//DTD PLIST 1.0//EN" "http://www.apple.com/DTDs/PropertyList-1.0.dtd">
<plist version="1.0">
</plist>
```

When this code is ran:
```python
import ujson

with open('test.plist', 'rb') as plist:
    ujson.dumps(plist)
```

it will work properly on MacOS, but it will break with the following error on Ubuntu:

`TypeError: � is not JSON serializable`

I currently don't have access to MacOS machine, but since it works there, I'm not sure if it's even relevant.

Ubuntu version is 18.04 LTS. It's a clean VM, with only l2tp gnome network manager, git and  pycharm installed.
Python version is 3.6.9 that came with Ubuntu.
Ujson version is 2.0.1. I've also added xxhash, termcolor and nose2 of other pip3 packages, but I don't see it as relevant.

I've attached the code and the plist that's triggering the error in the zip archive below:
[ujson_plist_wtr.zip](https://github.com/ultrajson/ultrajson/files/4332838/ujson_plist_wtr.zip)

Just running the .py file with the plist file in the same folder should trigger the error.

If you need any more info, I'll be happy to add it.

items.title: Drop support for EOL Python 2.7
items.body:
Python 2.7 is EOL since 2020-01-01.

At some point during 2020, support for Python 2.7 will be dropped, and released as a new major version, UltraJSON 3.0.

UltraJSON 2.x will be the last to support Python 2.7 and will remain available on PyPI.

The `python_requires` metadata will help those with modern pip (v9+) get the newest version of UltraJSON that supports their Python version.

items.title: Using setuptools_scm in pyproject.toml
items.body:
Hey,

Now that the project uses `setuptools_scm` in `setup_requires`, we are not able of building wheels for this this project in a sandbox, as setuptools will try to reach to the network.

Using `setuptools_scm` inside of Pyproject.toml would help us a great deal and is also the recommended way: https://github.com/pypa/setuptools_scm#pyprojecttoml-usage

Would it be possible to adapt this new style?

Thanks!

items.title: Error when installing ujson in Docker image python:3.8-slim-buster
items.body:
Hello, I have the following Dockerfile:

```dockerfile
FROM python:3.8-slim-buster

RUN pip install ujson
```

I tried to run a Docker container with the Dockerfile above and it gives the following error message:
```
Building wheels for collected packages: ujson
  Building wheel for ujson (PEP 517): started
  Building wheel for ujson (PEP 517): finished with status 'error'
  ERROR: Command errored out with exit status 1:
   command: /usr/local/bin/python /usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pip/_vendor/pep517/_in_process.py build_wheel /tmp/tmpm6uqjbu8

  creating build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.8/lib
  creating build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.8/python
  gcc -pthread -Wno-unused-result -Wsign-compare -DNDEBUG -g -fwrapv -O3 -Wall -fPIC -I./python -I./lib -I./deps/double-conversion/double-conversion -I/usr/local/include/python3.8 -c ./deps/double-conversion/double-conversion/fast-dtoa.cc -o build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.8/./deps/double-conversion/double-conversion/fast-dtoa.o -D_GNU_SOURCE
  error: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1
  ----------------------------------------
  ERROR: Failed building wheel for ujson
Failed to build ujson
ERROR: Could not build wheels for ujson which use PEP 517 and cannot be installed directly
```

I have also tried with `python setup.py install` and it gives the same error.

I found that if I install `g++` it works fine:

```dockerfile
FROM python:3.8-slim-buster

RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y --no-install-recommends g++

RUN pip install ujson
```

Also, it works with no problems with the Docker image `python:3.8-buster`.

However, I wanted to ask if there is a way to install `ujson` in `python:3.8-slim-buster` without this workaround.

Thanks!

items.title: 2.0: Removed generic serialization of objects

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

items.body:
We're having some code, that dumps a django.db.models.query.ValuesQuerySet

Pre ujson 1.35 code nicely creates a json.

With 2.0.1 we encounter following error:
'' [ .....] is not is not JSON serializable"|

What makes the code difficult to understand is, that repr() of a django.db.models.query.ValuesQuerySet is identical to a list, which is perfectly json serializable.

Question:

Is it intentional, (for performance reasons) that Querysets are no more serializable or is this an accidental regression?

items.title: TestPyPI install: ERROR: No matching distribution found for setuptools>=40.8.0
items.body:
> Let's say version 1.36.dev87 on TestPyPI is the release candidate, to be released as 2.0.0.
> 
> Please could you give it a go? If there's no major regressions in a few days, let's do the release.
> 
>     * https://test.pypi.org/project/ujson/1.36.dev87/
> 
> 
> ```
> pip install -i https://test.pypi.org/simple/ ujson==1.36.dev87
> ```

Does not work (neither with 2.7 nor 3.7):
```console
# pip install -i https://test.pypi.org/simple/ ujson==1.36.dev87
[..]
  ERROR: No matching distribution found for setuptools>=40.8.0
[..]
```
Prior `pip install 'setuptools>=40.8.0'` does not help.
My impression is that `https://test.pypi.org/` is both broken and dangerous to use (..).
I would recommend testing with this command, instead:
```console
# pip install git+https://github.com/ultrajson/ultrajson && python -c 'import ujson; print(ujson.loads("[1, 2]"))'
```

_Originally posted by @hartwork in https://github.com/ultrajson/ultrajson/issues/352#issuecomment-594591079_

items.title: Autodeploy to PyPI
items.body:
For non-tagged commits to master, deploy to TestPyPI.
* This is to test the release machinery itself and make sure it's working smoothly when it's time for a full release.
* It also provides snapshot releases for testing.

For tags, deploy to PyPI.

I'd suggest using API tokens:
* https://pypi.org/help/#apitoken

items.title: UltraJSON 2.0.0 release checklist
items.body:
Seeing as it's been over 4 years since the last release, and because support some  EOL Python versions have been dropped in that time, I propose the next release should bump to version 2.0.0. Python 2.7 support should be retained for this one.

Some things that come to mind to make a new release:

* [x] Move https://github.com/esnme/ultrajson to https://github.com/ultrajson/ultrajson
   * @cgbystrom Please could you do the transfer? [Instructions here](https://help.github.com/en/github/administering-a-repository/transferring-a-repository#transferring-a-repository-owned-by-your-organization).

* [x] Review and merge [open PRs](https://github.com/esnme/ultrajson/pulls)
   * Reviews welcome from everyone, please comment those which are most important 

* [x] Get access to https://pypi.org/project/ujson/
   * I've emailed previous maintainer Jonas to ask him to add @cgbystrom, @rstms and me to PyPI (same usernames) 

* [x] Get access to https://test.pypi.org/project/ujson/
   * @segfault I see you've been using this for experimenting, would you mind adding @cgbystrom, @rstms and @hugovk too?
   * https://test.pypi.org/manage/project/ujson/collaboration/

* [x] Set up Travis CI to deploy to TestPyPI on merge to master (to test the release machinery) and to PyPI on tags
  * I can set this up, it depends on previous two items

* [x] Anything else?

items.title: invalid parsing of big double value
items.body:
Run this code (indent by : of previous line):
```python
import ujson

def create_json_string(value):
    return "{\"x\":" + value + "}"

num = (2 ** 64) / 9

def inputs():
    yield str(num) + "77777777777777777777777"
    yield str(num) + "9"
    yield str(num) + "0"

for input_str in inputs():
    try:
        json_str = create_json_string(input_str)
        js = ujson.loads(json_str)
        print ("json "+json_str+" returned x=" + str(js['x']))
    except Exception as e:
        print ("json "+json_str+" returned error: "+str(e))
```

The result is:
```
> json {"x":204963823041217240177777777777777777777777} returned x=2049638230412172401
json {"x":20496382304121724019} returned x=2049638230412172403
json {"x":20496382304121724010} returned error: Value is too big!
```

The problem is that the number 204963823041217240177777777777777777777777 should raise "Value is too big!" exception.
The reason is that in ultrajsondec.c: , at the line "if (intNeg == 1 && prevIntValue > intValue)" , comparing intValue to prevIntValue doesn't indicate that the number is too long. You need to compare it to MAX_VALUE / 10.

items.title: Is ultrajson abandoned?
items.body:
My team (and seemingly many other teams around the world) depend on this library for day to day work and we love it. However, there have not been any commits/accepted PR's in several years and the latest commits are not even available as a published package. Is this library abandoned? I would gladly volunteer some time to do code review and package maintenance if you are looking for contribs.

If the library is completely abandoned and nobody is home, I will probably create a maintained fork of this package.

items.title: OverflowError error message description should be improved
items.body:
Right now, `ujson` gives this error when you try to encode certain types (e.g. `numpy.bool_`) that cannot be encoded:
```
OverflowError: Maximum recursion level reached
```

For example, you can get this error by running this code:
```python
import numpy
import ujson
print(ujson.dumps(numpy.bool_(True)))
```

This error does not indicate what actually went wrong, which is that `numpy.bool_` objects cannot be encoded.

As a basic fix for this problem, I'd suggest changing the error message to:
```
OverflowError: Maximum recursion level reached (maybe you tried encoding a type of object that isn't supported?)
```

items.title: For anyone who want to use ujson with NumPy's int64
items.body:
Hi,

My colleague and I have been working on a fork project to support NumPy's int64 under Python3: [caiyunapp/ultrajson](https://github.com/caiyunapp/ultrajson).

All you need to do is `pip install nujson` and `import nujson as ujson`.

What we mainly change is call NumPy's header in C, you can see https://github.com/caiyunapp/ultrajson/commit/187bd155b7acd303aa6f5571f5b858c0d244edd6 for details.

Either URL should be stringified (`str(url)`), or `dumps` should raise an error (like stdlib `json.dumps` does).

items.title: Incorrect float value when dumping to file
items.body:
Python 3.6.3 from Anaconda, using `ujson` version 1.35.

The following should save beta as 0.3 (as with the original `json` package) and not 0.30000000004.

~~~python
#!/usr/bin/env python3

import json, ujson

result = {
        'beta': 0.3,
        'alpha': 0.1,
        }

number = result['beta']**23
with open('./test_json.json', 'w') as f:
    json.dump(result, f)

with open('./test_ujson.json', 'w') as f:
    ujson.dump(result, f)

with open('./test_json.json', 'r') as f:
    print(json.load(f))  # {'beta': 0.3, 'alpha': 0.1}

with open('./test_ujson.json', 'r') as f:
    print(ujson.load(f))  # {'beta': 0.30000000000000004, 'alpha': 0.1}
~~~

items.title: `ujson.loads` parses `int` to `long`
items.body:
Version `1.35` python 2.7

`ujson.loads` implicitly parses `int` to `long` while `json.loads` does not.

```python
>>> import sys, json, ujson
>>> s = '{"a": %s }' % sys.maxint
>>> s
'{"a": 9223372036854775807 }'
>>> ujson.loads(s)
{u'a': 9223372036854775807L}
>>> json.loads(s)
{u'a': 9223372036854775807}
```

items.title: Little fix to create ultrajson wheel windows+python3.3 (SublimeText3)
Wrong rounds in dumps with double precision
items.body:
Hi,

I have experienced some cases where the ujson.dumps() function returns unexpected values when I use double_precision parameter.

```pycon
>>> ujson.dumps(1.9999999999999996, double_precision=15)
'1.1'
```
Any idea why is that happening?
Thank you in advance for your attention to this matter

items.title: Drop support for EOL Python versions?
items.body:
Is there any interest in dropping support for old Python versions? When they reach EOL that means they're no longer receiving security updates.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1324225/34263159-38b766bc-e677-11e7-918b-54bc889cfff0.png)

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CPython#Version_history

---

README says "Python 2.5+ and 3.".

setup.py suggests these are supported:
```
Programming Language :: Python :: 2.6
Programming Language :: Python :: 2.7
Programming Language :: Python :: 3
Programming Language :: Python :: 3.2
Programming Language :: Python :: 3.4
```

These are tested on Travis:
```
  - "2.6"
  - "2.7"
  - "3.3"
  - "3.4"
  - "3.5"
```

---

Here's the pip installs for ujson from PyPI for the last month (via `pypinfo --percent --pip --markdown ujson pyversion`)

| python_version | percent | download_count |
| -------------- | ------: | -------------: |
| 2.7            |   74.3% |        368,219 |
| 3.5            |   12.6% |         62,342 |
| 3.6            |    8.5% |         42,344 |
| 3.4            |    3.9% |         19,144 |
| 2.6            |    0.6% |          3,040 |
| 3.7            |    0.0% |            186 |
| 3.3            |    0.0% |             41 |
| 3.2            |    0.0% |             25 |

From these numbers, it looks like EOL versions 2.5, 2.6, 3.2 and 3.3 could safely be dropped.

This would allow the code to be modernised and ease the maintenance burden somewhat.

items.title: Segfault when dumping with 'indent' option
items.body:
Possibly related to #292, segfaults when dumping numpy objects with 'indent' option set. Without the indent option an OverflowError is thrown.  

Using conda distributed version of 1.35
```sh
$ conda list | grep ujson  
ujson                     1.35                     py36_0
```

Minimal example:
```sh
$ python -c 'import numpy; import ujson; ujson.dumps(numpy.int64(1), indent=4)'
Segmentation fault: 11
```

items.title: Segfault when dumping with `sort_keys=True`
items.body:
Hello,

There are cases when the library fails terribly crashing all the Python interpreter with a segmentation fault.

My versions:
```
$ python --version
Python 3.6.3
$ pip freeze | grep ujson
ujson==1.35
```

Here is a really small example:
```bash
$ python -c 'import ujson; ujson.dumps({0: 0, "1": {}}, sort_keys=False)'
$ python -c 'import ujson; ujson.dumps({0: 0, "1": {}}, sort_keys=True)'
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
```

Based on standard `json` module I believe this might be the reason:
```bash
$ python -c 'import json; json.dumps({0: 0, "1": {}}, sort_keys=True)'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.6/json/__init__.py", line 238, in dumps
    **kw).encode(obj)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.6/json/encoder.py", line 199, in encode
    chunks = self.iterencode(o, _one_shot=True)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.6/json/encoder.py", line 257, in iterencode
    return _iterencode(o, 0)
TypeError: '<' not supported between instances of 'str' and 'int'
```

---
For people out there having troubles with that, there is a drop-in replacement gentoo fork (`pip install ujsongp`; https://github.com/cordalace/ultrajson) which has this fixed:
```
$ python -c 'import ujson; ujson.dumps({0: 0, "1": {}}, sort_keys=True)'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
ValueError: unorderable keys
```

---

Any chances of fixing this? The easiest way might be to pull changes made in the gentoo fork...

items.title: Is this project still maintained?
items.body:
We've been using ujson for years in Zulip (github.com/zulip/zulip/), but recently had to fork it to do a small Python 3 fix (https://github.com/esnme/ultrajson/pull/284) when we migrated to Python 3.

I was looking at the repository more recently, and noticed that very little has happened in the last 3 months, and a few at least have comments from users asking if there's anything that can be done to get them unwedged (with no reply).

I realize that everyone in open source is busy, but I figured I'd ask, in case this is a situation where the project could use help from another maintainer (I don't personally have time, but from the PRs, there appear to be several folks putting time into fixing issues they're seeing using the project..).

items.title: ujson.loads throws SystemError instead of ValueError when a dict in the json is a key.
items.body:
Example:

```python
import ujson
ujson.loads('{{"a":true,` "b":"a"}:true, "b":"a"}')
```

Expected:

ujson should raise a ValueError.

Actual:

```
TypeError: unhashable type: 'dict'

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
SystemError: <built-in function loads> returned a result with an error set
```

This repros for me with ujson 1.35 on Python 3.5.2

items.title: dumping time object fails with OverflowError
items.body:

items.title: floats are getting rounded during serialization (precision loss)
should not serialize bytes
items.body:
We recently hit a bug (https://github.com/Kinto/kinto/issues/1224) where one code path round-tripped a bcrypt-hashed password (a `bytes` object) through ujson, and another code path didn't. The one that went through ujson converted everything to `str`, whereas the other one left it as `bytes`.

It's my opinion that `bytes` should not be a serializable type. There is no equivalent to `bytes` in JSON, but ujson encodes `bytes` as a JSON string, which is for code points, not bytes. This means that there are `bytes` values which are not representable in JSON. ujson tries its best, decoding bytes values as UTF8 and failing if that isn't possible:

```pycon
>>> import ujson
>>> ujson.dumps({"hi": b'\x30'})
'{"hi":"0"}'
>>> ujson.dumps({"hi": b'\xff'})
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xff in position 7: invalid start byte
```

This behavior made sense in the days of Python 2, where `str` objects were often used to encode text (see #74), but I think that if it's going to come out as strings, it shouldn't be allowed in as bytes.

The built-in `json` module refuses to encode `bytes`, either as a value or as an Object key:

```pycon
>>> import json
>>> json.dumps({"hi": b'\x30'})
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/json/__init__.py", line 230, in dumps
    return _default_encoder.encode(obj)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/json/encoder.py", line 198, in encode
    chunks = self.iterencode(o, _one_shot=True)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/json/encoder.py", line 256, in iterencode
    return _iterencode(o, 0)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/json/encoder.py", line 179, in default
    raise TypeError(repr(o) + " is not JSON serializable")
TypeError: b'0' is not JSON serializable
>>> json.dumps({b"hi": b'\x30'})
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/json/__init__.py", line 230, in dumps
    return _default_encoder.encode(obj)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/json/encoder.py", line 198, in encode
    chunks = self.iterencode(o, _one_shot=True)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/json/encoder.py", line 256, in iterencode
    return _iterencode(o, 0)
TypeError: keys must be a string
```

items.title: Maximum recursion level reached when circular reference
Support serializing datetime objects to ISO-8601 strings
items.body:
Currently, `ujson.dumps` will serialize a `datetime.datetime` instance to a unix timestamp (integer). The [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) format seems to be a more popular standard for these values. Other projects, such as [`python-rapidjson`](https://github.com/python-rapidjson/python-rapidjson) solve this by [adding flags to choose which format to use](https://python-rapidjson.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html).

Would it be possible to add support for serializing to ISO-8601?

items.title: Sorting keys in the given order
items.body:
Hi!

Speaking of the very JSON format, an object is an `unordered set of name/value pairs`, and the key order doesn't make a lot of sense. But sometimes it's quite useful to have a json with the keys sorted in a custom way. For example, in case you work with json-API manually and want the most important parts to be on the top of a big response.

The original `json` library proposes a solution to the problem. You only have to use the `collections.OrderedDict`:
```python
>>> json.dumps(OrderedDict([(3,1), (2,3), (-1,5), ("0",16), (-100,{}), (958,4)]))
'{"3": 1, "2": 3, "-1": 5, "0": 16, "-100": {}, "958": 4}'
```

But `ujson` doesn't:
```python
>>> ujson.dumps(OrderedDict([(3,1), (2,3), (-1,5), ("0",16), (-100,{}), (958,4)]))
 '{"2":3,"3":1,"0":16,"-1":5,"-100":{},"958":4}'

>>> ujson.dumps(OrderedDict([(3,1), (2,3), (-1,5), ("0",16), (-100,{}), (958,4)]), sort_keys=True)
'{"-100":{},"-1":5,"2":3,"3":1,"958":4,"0":16}'

>>> ujson.dumps(OrderedDict([(3,1), (2,3), (-1,5), ("0",16), (-100,{}), (958,4)]), sort_keys=False)
'{"2":3,"3":1,"0":16,"-1":5,"-100":{},"958":4}'

>>> ujson.dumps(OrderedDict([(3,1), (2,3), (-1,5), ("0",16), (-100,{}), (958,4)]), sort_keys=None)
'{"2":3,"3":1,"0":16,"-1":5,"-100":{},"958":4}'
```
Although [the answer to the similar question](http://stackoverflow.com/a/38265539/2116625) on StackOverflow says it should, when `sort_keys=False` is provided.

Can you please add the feature of dumping `dict`s in the exact order of their `.items()`?

```
Fatal Python error: ./python/objToJSON.c:934 object at 0x7fa13e088ba0 has negative ref count -1
Aborted (core dumped)
```

This seems to happen with any dictionary, even empty ones. Works fine without `sort_keys=True`, and sometimes works fine on non-debug build of Python, but it caused at least one hard to catch segfault for me.

items.title: Serialising Pandas NaT causes a SegFault
items.body:
I've fixed this by trivially filtering out pandas.tslib.NaT before serialising it, but I'm wondering if there is a gracious way of handling this, without segfaulting.

Trivial code to reproduce is:
```
import pandas as pd
import ujson
ujson.encode(pd.NaT)

Segmentation fault: 11  /Users/ross/anaconda/python.app/Contents/MacOS/python "$@"
```

items.title: OrderedDict is not "ordered" when dumps
items.body:
ujson not remember the order of OrderedDict object.
Here is an example:
```
$ python3
Python 3.5.1 (default, Sep 19 2016, 10:16:17) 
[GCC 6.1.1 20160621 (Red Hat 6.1.1-3)] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import ujson
>>> import json
>>> from collections import OrderedDict
>>> o=OrderedDict()
>>> o[1] = 1
>>> o[0] = 0
>>> o[8] = 8
>>> o[2] = 2
>>> print(o)
OrderedDict([(1, 1), (0, 0), (8, 8), (2, 2)])
>>> ujson.dumps(o)
'{"0":0,"1":1,"2":2,"8":8}'
>>> json.dumps(o)
'{"1": 1, "0": 0, "8": 8, "2": 2}'
```

items.title: ujson.dumps yields invalid JSON
items.body:
Hi,

I have the following Python dictionary

```
{"first_name": u"team5__", "last_name": "team5", "account_type": "unlimited", "registration_date": "2016-09-28T09:29:45.548548+00:00", "networks": [], "avatar": None, "team": {"member_type_name": "Super Administrator", "domain": "1234567890.com", "stats": {"recipients": 0, "sent": 0}, 
"name": 1234567890123456789012345678901234567890123456789012345678901234567890123456789012345678901234567890L, 
"perms": 137438953471, 
"members_summary": {"resharers": 0, "admins": 1, "senders": 0, "viewers": 0}, "member_type": 16, "phone": "1234567890", "size": "1234567890", "id": 92, "job_title": None}, "stats": {"recipients": 0, "sent": 0}, "emails": {"primary": "team5__@mailinator.com", "secondary": []}, "plan": "team"}
```

The problem here is that `name` points to a very large float number. `ujson.dumps()` is unable to convert it into JavaScript float value. However, it does not raise an exception or yield False value. Instead, it produces an invalid JSON.

```
Python 2.7.12 (default, Jul  1 2016, 15:12:24)
[GCC 5.4.0 20160609] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import ujson
>>> print ujson.__version__
1.35
>>> my_data = {"first_name": u"team5__", "last_name": "team5", "account_type": "unlimited", "registration_date": "2016-09-28T09:29:45.548548+00:00", "networks": [], "avatar": None, "team": {"member_type_name": "Super Administrator", "domain": "1234567890.com", "stats": {"recipients": 0, "sent": 0}, "name": 1234567890123456789012345678901234567890123456789012345678901234567890123456789012345678901234567890L, "perms": 137438953471, "members_summary": {"resharers": 0, "admins": 1, "senders": 0, "viewers": 0}, "member_type": 16, "phone": "1234567890", "size": "1234567890", "id": 92, "job_title": None}, "stats": {"recipients": 0, "sent": 0}, "emails": {"primary": "team5__@mailinator.com", "secondary": []}, "plan": "team"}
>>> ujson.dumps(my_data)
'{"first_name":"team5__","last_name":"team5","account_type":"unlimited","avatar":null,"team":{"domain":"1234567890.com","perms":137438953471,"member_type":16,"phone":"1234567890","id":92,"size":"1234567890","member_type_name":"Super Administrator","stats":{"sent":0,"recipients":0},"name":,"members_summary":{"resharers":0,"admins":1,"senders":0,"viewers":0},"job_title":null},"stats":{"sent":0,"recipients":0},"plan":"team","registration_date":"2016-09-28T09:29:45.548548+00:00","networks":[],"emails":{"primary":"team5__@mailinator.com","secondary":[]}}'
>>>
```

As you can see, the resulting JSON is not valid

```
{"first_name":"team5__","last_name":"team5","account_type":"unlimited","avatar":null,"team":{"domain":"1234567890.com","perms":137438953471,"member_type":16,"phone":"1234567890","id":92,"size":"1234567890","member_type_name":"Super Administrator","stats":{"sent":0,"recipients":0},
"name":,
"members_summary":{"resharers":0,"admins":1,"senders":0,"viewers":0},"job_title":null},"stats":{"sent":0,"recipients":0},"plan":"team","registration_date":"2016-09-28T09:29:45.548548+00:00","networks":[],"emails":{"primary":"team5__@mailinator.com","secondary":[]}}
```

items.title: Two versions of ultrajson exist on PyPi
items.body:
Hi,

On PyPi currently two different projects exists for this one codebase:
- https://pypi.python.org/pypi/ujson, which as a download link refers to this repo (http://github.com/esnme/ultrajson)
- https://pypi.python.org/pypi/ultrajson, which as a download link refers to a fork of this repo (https://github.com/darthghandi/ultrajson)

Maybe it is best to somehow just have one project on PyPi?

Cheers,
Remco

items.title: Dumping `Decimal` is raising Max recursion depth exceeded error on uwsgi
items.body:
```
import ujson
import decimal
ujson.dumps(decimal.Decimal(u'80.00'))
```

When run above code in a python shell it works fine. When I run it in a Apache mod_wsgi process it works fine. But when I run it in uwsgi process (which gets request from an Nginx server with uwsgi_pass) it raises following error.

**OverflowError: Maximum recursion level reached**

items.title: Can user provide a filter on fields?
items.body:
In python, decoding a big object is expensive. There are scenarios that not all fields are necessary (for example we just need to extract user_id from user action logs, which contains a lot of fields, however, other fields are not used).
Is there a way to filter out unnecessary field during decoding to improve performance?

items.title: Strange bug with LONG
items.body:
Finded some really strange bug
ujson version 1.35

``` python
> ujson.dumps({'params': [1, 18446744073709551616L], 'method': ''})
'{"params":[1,],"method":""}'

> ujson.dumps({'params': [1, 18446744073709551616L], 'test': ''})
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
OverflowError: long too big to convert
```

as you can see in first example encoder silently ignore LONG and return incorrect data, but in second example it raise error

This is repost from closed #99
